Sorry, I have made a mistake and I have corrected that.
The problem I face is with implementation of aggregation operators like mean and max. I have all instances from all bags stored in one matrix. Then on basis of "meta" information I average all instances from each bag. This operation leads to matrix with the same number of features but with number of samples equal to the number of bags. That said, I cannot used mean over one dimension  of the tensor, each bag gas different number of instances. Does mxnet support this operator?

i also tried to load the CIFAR10 data into R array format and do normalization, then train the CNN by this model, same situation happened.

here is my R script for loading CIFAR10 into R array format.

rm(list=ls())
library(mxnet)
library(imager)

setwd("/home/mac/R_Projects/MXnet/CIFAR-10")

Lists <- read.table("trainLabels_new.csv", header = TRUE, sep=",")
files <- list.files("./train/")

a <- array(0, c(32,32,3,20000))
train.y <- c()

for (i in 1:20000) {
  filename <- paste("",Lists$id[i],".png", sep="")
  if (length(intersect(filename, files)) == 1) {path <- paste("./train/",filename,"", sep="")
  test <- load.image(path)
  a[1:32,1:32,1,i] <- R(test)
  a[1:32,1:32,2,i] <- G(test)
  a[1:32,1:32,3,i] <- B(test)
  train.y[i] <- Lists$label[i]
  }
}

train.array <- a
train.sd.array <- a
mean.array <- array(0, c(32,32,3))
sd.array <- array(0, c(32,32,3))

for (j in 1:32){
  for (k in 1:32){
    for (l in 1:3){
      mean.array[j,k,l] <- mean(a[j,k,l,])
      sd.array[j,k,l] <- sd(a[j,k,l,])
    }
  }
}

for (m in 1:20000){
  train.array[,,,m] <- a[,,,m] - mean.array
  train.sd.array[,,,m] <- (a[,,,m] - mean.array)/sd.array
}

id <- sample(1:20000, 2000)

normal.val.array <- a[,,,id]
normal.val.y <- train.y[id]
normal.test.array <- a[,,,-id]
normal.test.y <- train.y[-id]

mean.val.array <- train.array[,,,id]
mean.val.y <- train.y[id]
mean.test.array <- train.array[,,,-id]
mean.test.y <- train.y[-id]

sd.val.array <- train.sd.array[,,,id]
sd.val.y <- train.y[id]
sd.test.array <- train.sd.array[,,,-id]
sd.test.y <- train.y[-id]

normal.train <- mx.io.arrayiter(data = normal.test.array, label = normal.test.y, batch.size = 100, shuffle = TRUE)
normal.val <- mx.io.arrayiter(data = normal.val.array, label = normal.val.y, batch.size = 100, shuffle = TRUE)

mean.train <- mx.io.arrayiter(data = mean.test.array, label = mean.test.y, batch.size = 100, shuffle = TRUE)
mean.val <- mx.io.arrayiter(data = mean.val.array, label = mean.val.y, batch.size = 100, shuffle = TRUE)

sd.train <- mx.io.arrayiter(data = sd.test.array, label = sd.test.y, batch.size = 100, shuffle = TRUE)
sd.val <- mx.io.arrayiter(data = sd.val.array, label = sd.val.y, batch.size = 100, shuffle = TRUE)

Bind the symbol and shape yourself and run forward manually may help. 
The `mxnet.model.FeedForward.predict()` init the executor by calling `simple_bind()` every time you call it. If you make online predictions, you only need to call simple_bind one time and feed the inputs to the executor in sequence.

You can define your own `EvalMetric`. Refer to `mxnet/python/mxnet/metric.py`. The example below may help you.
https://github.com/xlvector/learning-dl/blob/master/mxnet/triple-loss/triplet_loss.py#L134

@Ldpe2G The immutable one lists the elements the same order as we init it (and the `+` or `++` operator, you can try). But for mutable one, you're right, it is confusing. Or we shall use `mutable.LinkedHashMap` instead? While I don't like mutable here.

If you bind manually, make sure your net inputs match the data_shapes especially when you have multiple inputs. In your case, make sure `t_iter.provide_data` is all the shape you should provide manually.

For example, open https://www.tensorflow.org/versions/r0.11/how_tos/index.html and start reducing the web page size. It reduces till acceptable width and donot change after that.

Headers will all get re-arranged.

This is achieved by:
1. Making header position relative
2. Fixing header <div> min width (Post that scroll bars comes in to picture)
I observe that we need to fix CSS issue in header. Created the issue https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/3531 with details on other issues in header and possible fixes.

Also you can reload your model,  convert your data to `numpy.array` format and feed it you `predict()`, the mxnet will take care of the shapes problems. This may also have the "shape" problem, but will no batch size problem.
